autoresponses.description: Auto-responses are a way to make the bot respond to triggers in regular messages.

extra.title: Auto-response triggers
extra.description: Triggers have four modes: `full`, `contains`, `words ordered`, and `words unordered`.
fields: Will only match if the entire message is the same as the trigger
Will match if the message contains the trigger anywhere inside it
Will match as long as the message contains all the trigger's words in it, in the order that they were provided
Will match as long as the message contains all the trigger's words in it. The order the words appear in doesn't matter
footer: For both words modes, other words can appear in between the required words.

extra.title: Auto-response types
fields: Will send a regular Discord message
Will send an image/gif/video in chat
Will send a message containing some URL buttons
Will react to the message with some emoji reactions

addautoresponse.description: Run a builder that adds a new auto-response for the server.

extra.description:
This command uses handlebars. Place these in the text to have them replaced in the command output.

```{{user}}      - Ping the user
{{username}}  - The user's username
{{name}}      - The user's display name
{{server}}    - The server name
{{owner}}     - Ping the server owner
{{bot}}       - Ping the bot
{{time}}      - The current time
{{date}}      - The current date
{{banappeal}} - The server's ban appeal link
{{prefix}}    - The bot's prefix in the server
{{channel}}   - Mention the current channel```

description: Remove an auto-response from the server.
Provide no arguments to view a list of active auto-responses.
View an auto-response from the server.
Provide no arguments to view a list of active auto-responses.
Custom commands are commands that you can configure to respond with whatever you want.
You can use "e!help custom" to view all the custom commands.

Custom command types:

Message: Will send a regular Discord message
Image/Gif/Video: Will send an image/gif/video in chat
Custom Embed: Will send a custom embed
URL Buttons: Will send a message containing some URL buttons

- Attachment
- URL
- Member

Leave the image argument blank to target an image from a previous message in the channel. You can also reply to a message or provide a message link to target an image in that message.

extra.description:
There are certain image prefixes and shortcuts that you can use to change the image input.

Users and members are different things. A member is a user that is inside a server, so therefore may have a different server specific avatar that is different from the user avatar.
fields: These work on any command that accepts a member, or an image:

```^    - Target the member from the previous message
self - Target yourself
me   - Target yourself
<    - Target yourself
<<   - Target your user
bot  - Target the bot```
These work on any command that accepts an image:

```Format: prefix:argument:optional_argument

b:@ping
 - get a users banner
u:@ping
 - get a user
colour:colour:size, color:colour:size
 - get a solid colour
mc:username, skin:username
 - get the minecraft skin of a Minecraft username
mc:@ping, skin:@ping
 - get the minecraft skin of a member
cape:username
 - get the minecraft cape of a Minecraft username
cape:@ping
 - get the minecraft cape of a member
texture:filename:version
 - get a minecraft texture```

description: Moderator pings are a system that allow members to quickly and easily get the attention of moderators for whatever reason is necessary.

During a mod ping, Wynem will ping three members of the lowest ranking moderator role, with 60 seconds between each ping. If no moderator has responded, it will ping the entire role. If still no one has responded, it repeats this process two more times with the next two higher tiers of moderator role.
By default, moderator role tiers are guessed, but they can be manually configured with the "setmodpingroles" command.
Modpings can also be triggered by pinging any role named "@Modping" or "@Moderator Ping"
Ping the moderators of the current server.
The roles can be configured with the "setmodpingroles" command
Set up to three custom roles to be used with moderator pings.
The order of the roles is the order of priority. Running this will overwrite any previously set roles. Provide no roles to remove the current ones.

togglemodping.description: Toggles the ability for users to trigger a moderator ping.

viewmodpingroles.description: View the roles set to be used in moderator pings.

Block users hiding Discord links inside a markdown disguised link:
`[message](https://discord.gg/pkRxtGw)`

Block users from using any markdown disguised links:
`[message](https://wynem.com/)`

Block users sending Discord invite links:
`https://discord.gg/pkRxtGw`

Block users sending large text using markdown:
`# THIS TEXT IS LARGE`
This will only work if the title is in the first line of the message

Block messages containing a continuous line of 35 or more characters:
`fhewruofhweouhfguipewgfufewhuopfbon`

description: Add a note to a member.
Members cannot see their notes.
The note is stored as a record and can be viewed at any time. There is a maximum of 50 records per member.

endtimeout.description: End the time out of a member who is timed out.

description: Kick a member from the server.
The member is sent a message saying they were kicked, along with the reason.
Bulk delete messages from a channel.
Defaults to 5, maximum 99.
Mention a user to delete only their messages.
This cannot delete messages that are over two weeks old.

records.description: View the moderation records for a member.

description: Give a member a time out so that they cannot type or speak.
Defaults to 10 minutes.
The member is sent a message saying they were timed out, along with the reason.
The time out is stored as a record and can be viewed at any time. There is a maximum of 50 records per member.
Give a member a warning.
The member is sent a message saying they were warned, along with the reason.
The warning is stored as a record and can be viewed at any time. There is a maximum of 50 records per member.

artchives.description: The Artchive™ is a channel where users can submit images to be archived. These could be artworks, memes, or literally anything. Its up to each server to decide what to use it for.

description: A starboard is a channel where messages are sent after they reach a certain number of a reaction, usually a star.

After a message is sent, it has 1 week to hit the required reaction count and appear in the starboard. After that, the message expires and is locked into its current starboard state and can no longer change.
Manage the starboards for the server.
Provide a channel to create a new starboard. Provide the same channel again to remove it.
Blacklist a category or channel from having its messages sent to a starboard.
Provide a channel to blacklist it. Provide the same channel again to unblacklist it.

description: The FAQ is a system to store frequently asked questions, so that you can quickly bring up the answers when they are asked.
The FAQ command supports fuzzy matching making it easy to lookup your FAQs. The FAQ management commands require exact categories and IDs to ensure you select the right one.

There is a maximum of 100 FAQs per server, and a maximum of 25 FAQ categories per server

Get the raw text from an FAQ entry.

Toggles whether the bot will notifiy you when someone ghost pings you.
Ghost ping notices are not sent when moderators delete messages (requires the bot to have audit log permissions).
Once a ping is 10 minutes old, it can be deleted without triggering a ghost ping alert.

togglequotes.description: Toggles whether the bot will quote a message whenever a message link is sent.

description: Toggles whether the bot will notifiy you when you reply to someone who has left the server.
Notices are only sent if the message you reply to is within the last 50 messages in a channel, and the bot has not already sent a notice in the last 10 messages.
Tickets is a system that allows users to create private tickets in a server that can be managed by users with a special role for handling tickets.
Tickets use their own channel where a message exists that allows users to create and close tickets.

When a user creates a ticket, they are shown a list of customisable ticket types, where they select the one relevant to their issue. Upon selecting the ticket type, one of two things will happen:

If the ticket type is set to "Create" mode, they will be presented with a customisable form that they then fill out with information related to the ticket type. Upon filling out the form, the ticket will be created.

If the ticket type is set to "Deny" mode, they will be shown a customisable message that explains why the ticket could not be created, useful for stopping people from creating tickets about certain topics.
Add a new ticket type.
The ticket types are the options that the user can select from when creating a ticket.

There are two types of ticket type:

Create: When creating the ticket, the user is shown a form that they need to fill in before the ticket is created.

Deny: The user is deined from creating a ticket and a custom message is shown to them. Useful for stopping people making tickets for things they shouldn't be making tickets about.
The ticket sort priority controls the order that the ticket types appear in the ticket type selection list.
Edit a ticket type.
Leave fields blank to leave them unedited.
Only limited editing is possible. For editing that removes stuff, changes type, or adds new entry fields, instead remove and re-add the ticket type.

removetickets.description: Remove the tickets system from the server.

removetickettype.description: Remove a ticket type from the tickets system.

description: Set a channel and role to be used for the tickets system.
The channel is where users will be able to create tickets. The channel should be an empty channel. The permissions will be changed so users cannot send messages there.
The role is the role that will be managing the tickets. When a ticket is created, the role members get added to the ticket, and a random role member gets pinged.

viewtickets.description: View the servers tickets system and the ticket types.

description: Add a new ticket type.
The ticket types are the options that the user can select from when creating a ticket.

There are two types of ticket type:

Create: When creating the ticket, the user is shown a form that they need to fill in before the ticket is created.

Deny: The user is deined from creating a ticket and a custom message is shown to them. Useful for stopping people making tickets for things they shouldn't be making tickets about.
The ticket sort priority controls the order that the ticket types appear in the ticket type selection list.
Edit a ticket type.
Leave fields blank to leave them unedited.
Only limited editing is possible. For editing that removes stuff, changes type, or adds new entry fields, instead remove and re-add the ticket type.

remove.description: Remove the tickets system from the server.

removetype.description: Remove a ticket type from the tickets system.

description: Set a channel and role to be used for the tickets system.
The channel is where users will be able to create tickets. The channel should be an empty channel. The permissions will be changed so users cannot send messages there.
The role is the role that will be managing the tickets. When a ticket is created, the role members get added to the ticket, and a random role member gets pinged.

description: Toggles whether the bot will notifiy you when you reply to someone who has left the server.

description: Ban a member from the server.
The member is sent a message saying they were banned, along with the reason.
